The great king might proudly number Sogdiana, and even Serica, among the provinces of his empire, but his real dominion was bounded by the Oxus; and his useful intercourse with the Sogdoites, beyond the river, depended on the pleasure of their conquerors, the white Huns, and the Turks, who succeflively reigned over that industrious people. Yet the most savage dominion has not extirpated the seeds of agriculture and commerce, in a region which is celebrated as one of the four gardens of Asia3 the cities of Samarcand and Bochara are advantageoussy seated for the exchange of its various productions3 and their mer- chants purchased from the Chinese⁶⁸ the raw or manufactured fill< which they transported into Perfla for the use of the Roman empire.
